item.title: Venezuelan Opposition Leader Steps Up Pressure, but Maduro Holds On
item.media:description: The opposition leader Juan Guaidó, left, with Leopoldo López, a member of his party who had been under house arrest after leading protests in 2014.
item.description: After Juan Guaidó said rebellion was at hand, supporters clashed with loyalists to the president. By day’s end, Mr. Guaidó fell short of the prize he sought.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: What Is Happening in Venezuela and Why It Matters
item.media:description: Supporters of the Venezuelan opposition in Caracas in January during a symbolic swearing-in ceremony for Juan Guaidó.
item.description: A basic guide to what has been happening in Venezuela, once one of Latin America's most prosperous countries, where a political and economic crisis has reached new heights.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Capri Dispatch: Capri Welcomes 2.3 Million Tourists a Year but Wants to Limit the Trash They Leave Behind
item.media:description: The tiny island of Capri, Italy, is under serious threat by those two endemic Italian scourges: tourists and trash.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: Capri has decreed a ban on plastic and would like to limit boat traffic, too, in an effort to control those twin Italian ills: tourism and trash.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Julian Assange Sentenced to 50 Weeks and Still Faces U.S. Charges
item.media:description: Julian Assange leaving Southwark Crown Court in London in a security van on Wednesday after he was sentenced.
item.description: A London court sentenced Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, to prison for jumping bail in 2012, but his legal troubles are far from over.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Violence Erupts at May Day Rally in Paris as Hooded Vandals Smash Vehicles
item.media:description: French police officers and protesters clashed in the Montparnasse area in Paris on Wednesday, before the start of the May Day rally in Paris.
item.description: The police in France fired tear gas after violence broke out at the labor rally, with masked vandals mixing with demonstrators and throwing rocks.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: One Image of Japan’s Royals Tells a Story of Demographic Crisis
item.media:description: Princess Aiko, 17, the daughter of Emperor Naruhito and his wife, Empress Masako, is not allowed to ascend to the throne.
item.description: Emperor Naruhito’s ascension ceremony offered striking visual evidence of the imperial family’s looming existential crisis: It has precious few heirs left.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH, HISAKO UENO and MAKIKO INOUE

item.title: Things ‘Stopped Changing’: Why Conflict Still Flares in Northern Ireland
item.media:description: The funeral of the young journalist Lyra McKee in Belfast last week. Her killing has brought renewed focus on the the latest incarnation of the Irish Republican Army.
item.media:credit: Liam Mcburney/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: The killing of a young journalist has brought renewed focus on the region’s paramilitary groups. But economic stagnation is as much a driver of violence as politics.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: Taliban and U.S. Start New Round of Talks in Qatar
item.media:description: American diplomats and representatives of the Taliban during earlier negotiations in Doha, Qatar, in February.
item.description: As fighting intensifies across Afghanistan, American and insurgent envoys — though none from the Afghan government — will discuss a possible troop withdrawal.
item.dc:creator: DAVID ZUCCHINO
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Venezuela: What We Know About Juan Guaidó’s ‘Final Phase’
item.media:description: Opposition demonstrators taking cover from tear gas near the Generalisimo Francisco de Miranda Air Base, also known as La Carlota, in Caracas on Tuesday.
item.description: The Venezuelan opposition leader has asked the military and civilians to rise up against President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: A Broken Skull, a Dubious Paper Trail: Australian Justice for One Aboriginal Man
item.media:description: During a meeting with Mr. Cumaiyi’s lawyer in Darwin last month, his aunt Stephanie Berida showed how his hands had been shackled as he was led to a police airplane.
item.media:credit: Glenn Campbell for The New York Times
item.description: Medical records obtained by The New York Times suggest Patrick Cumaiyi was a victim of police brutality that fits a pattern in Australia — including a cover-up.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE and BROOK MITCHELL

item.title: Attorney General, Venezuela, U.N.C. Charlotte: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.media:description: A bus in flames during protests in Caracas, Venezuela, on Tuesday.
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: You Can Make a Treadmill From These Common Household Items (but Don’t)
item.description: Internet users are posting videos of themselves exercising using nothing more than soap, water, a slick hard floor and maybe a lack of common sense.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR and TIFFANY MAY

item.title: The New New World: ‘Striding Across the Pacific’: Huawei’s Identity Problem
item.description: The Chinese telecom giant seeks acceptance in the West, but its structure and value system — patterned after the Communist Party’s — could stand in the way.
item.dc:creator: LI YUAN

item.title: U.S. Military Stops Counting How Much of Afghanistan Is Controlled by Taliban
item.media:description: Villagers in Khogyani, Afghanistan, an area largely under Taliban control, last year.
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.description: “It’s like turning off the scoreboard,” one American official said of the decision, which eliminates an important public measure of progress in the war.
item.dc:creator: DAVID ZUCCHINO
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Mueller, Venezuela, Deutsche Bank: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.media:description: Attorney General William Barr, center, during a news conference in April.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: MELINA DELKIC

item.title: Is the Muslim Brotherhood a Terrorist Group?
item.media:description: Tens of thousands of supporters demonstrated in support of President Mohamed Morsi, a member of the Muslim Brotherhood who was ousted by the military in 2013.
item.media:credit: Yusuf Sayman for The New York Times
item.description: President Trump wants to designate the Muslim Brotherhood as a terrorist organization. The group says it isn’t, an assessment that many experts share.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Emperor Naruhito Takes the Throne, and a New Era Arrives in Japan
item.media:description: The new emperor, Naruhito, with his wife, Masako, and their daughter, Aiko, in 2002.
item.description: Naruhito is likely to continue to stress the pacifism and war remembrance of his father, Akihito, as well as his efforts to humanize the monarchy.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Photos From Venezuela: A Protest Turns Violent
item.media:description: Juan Guaidó, the Venezuelan opposition leader, talking to supporters in Caracas on Tuesday.
item.description: An opposition leader said it was time for the people to rise up. It was not clear how many were listening.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Robert Mueller, Venezuela, Tony Awards: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: REMY TUMIN and SARAH ECKINGER

item.title: Yeti Footprints Found in Nepal Are Maybe (Definitely) From a Bear
item.media:description: A team of Indian Army mountaineers spotted a set of large footprints in the snow in the northeastern Himalayas in April.
item.description: The Indian Army posted photos on Twitter of what they believed were the footprints of a yeti. Social media responded with theories of its own.
item.dc:creator: SANDRA E. GARCIA

item.title: At War: Why Whales and Dolphins Join the Navy, in Russia and the U.S.
item.media:description: Commodore Tony Millar, of the Royal New Zealand Navy, tossed a fish to a bottlenose dolphin during a visit to United States Naval Base Point Loma in July 2018.
item.description: A former Navy officer who is now a New York Times reporter explains how the American military trains marine mammals for underwater operations.
item.dc:creator: JOHN ISMAY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Mavis Pusey, Under-the-Radar Abstract Artist, Is Dead at 90
item.media:description: Ms. Pusey’s "Dejygea” was on view in 1971 in the exhibition “Contemporary Black Artists in America" at the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York.
item.description: She favored bold geometric forms, especially in works inspired by urban construction and demolition in New York City.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GENZLINGER

item.title: Japan, Venezuela, Apple: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.media:description: Clashes between supporters of Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaidó and soldiers and police officers erupted on Tuesday.
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: ALISHA HARIDASANI GUPTA

item.title: Venezuelan National Guard Vehicles Hit Demonstrators
item.description: In this video, an armored vehicle can be seen driving into a group of demonstrators during clashes in Venezuela between anti-government protesters and law enforcement officers in Caracas.

item.title: The Interpreter: ‘Overrun,’ ‘Outbred,’ ‘Replaced’: Why Ethnic Majorities Lash Out Over False Fears
item.media:description: Buddhists at Kelaniya Temple in Colombo, Sri Lanka’s capital. Though the Sinhalese, who are mostly Buddhist, make up three-quarters of Sri Lanka’s population, many see themselves as an embattled minority.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Around the world, long-dominant groups see themselves as under siege, driving the rise of right-populism, religious nationalism and white terrorism.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER and AMANDA TAUB

item.title: A Holocaust Story for the Social Media Generation
item.media:description: A billboard in Tel Aviv for “Eva Stories,” a Holocaust education project.
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.description: Eva Heyman kept a diary until she was sent to Auschwitz in 1944. An Instagram version of her story goes live this week, but some Israelis say it trivializes the Holocaust.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Guaidó Calls for an Uprising in Venezuela
item.description: The Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaidó called for the military to rise up against the government of President Nicolás Maduro on Tuesday.

item.title: Venezuela Crisis: Guaidó Calls for Uprising as Clashes Erupt
item.media:description: Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaidó rallying supporters in Caracas on Tuesday.
item.description: The situation appeared to take a new turn after Juan Guaidó appeared at a military base in Caracas.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Asylum Seekers, Japan, John Singleton: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: These Five Cuisines Are Easier on the Planet
item.media:description: Hot and cold dishes at Beit El Qamar near Beirut, Lebanon.
item.media:credit: Ieva Saudargaité for The New York Times
item.description: There is no magic cuisine to save our species. There are, however, many ways to eat sustainably.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Afghanistan Dispatch: In Afghan Blood Sports, the Animals Aren’t the Only Ones Fighting
item.media:description: Honeybee and Leopard, with their handlers around them, during a dogfight in Mazar-i-Sharif, Afghanistan, last month.
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.description: In Afghanistan, dogfights attract packed stadiums and big purses. Fighting birds and even camels also feed the Afghan love of animal “sports,” although religious leaders decry them as sinful.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Sri Lanka’s President Lifts Ban on Social Media
item.media:description: Security personnel and bystanders in front of St. Anthony’s Shrine in Colombo, Sri Lanka, last week. The church was one of three hit by suicide attacks on Easter.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The social media ban in the wake of the Easter attacks reflected global concern about the role the networks play in spreading hate speech and inciting communal violence.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Sri Lanka, ISIS, British Police: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.media:description: Security personnel in front of St. Anthony’s Shrine in Colombo, Sri Lanka, where terrorists attacked on Easter Sunday.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: MELINA DELKIC and ALISHA HARIDASANI GUPTA

item.title: survival of the throne: episode five: The Suitor With the Shaggy Hair
item.description: Princess Mako was never getting anywhere near the Japanese throne. But the public still seemed to have a say over her romantic life.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Survival of the throne: episode two: The Long Shadows of a Failed War
item.media:description: Akihito and Michiko departing for Okinawa in 1975.
item.media:credit: The Asahi Shimbun, via Getty Images
item.description: A Japanese royal sought to make peace with the lands his country had once conquered. But at home, too, there were fences to mend.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Survival of the throne: Episode four: A Princess in a Cage
item.media:description: Princess Masako and Crown Prince Naruhito with their daughter, Aiko, at the imperial estate in 2007.
item.media:credit: Imperial Household Agency, via Getty Images
item.description: The survival of Japan’s monarchy rested on her shoulders. No one ever let her forget it.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Survival of the throne: Episode one: Japan Would Make Akihito Emperor, but She Called Him ‘Jimmy’
item.media:description: An undated photo of Emperor Hirohito and the royal family.
item.description: An American teacher taught the young prince he would never be a god. But he just might help heal his country.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Survival of the throne: episode three: The Reluctant Bride
item.description: She had her sights on a career in diplomacy. The Japanese prince had his sights on her.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Xi Praises a Student Protest in China. From 100 Years Ago.
item.media:description: Visitors taking a photo with a Communist Youth League flag at an exhibition in the New Culture Movement Memorial Museum in Beijing, last week.
item.media:credit: Yan Cong for The New York Times
item.description: The Chinese leader marked the historic May 4 protest against Western colonialism. But under his brand of authoritarianism, even a demonstration from a century ago is tricky.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and AMY QIN

item.title: MS-13 Gang Put Fake Body in Car, Then Detonated a Bomb When Police Came
item.media:description: Police in El Salvador investigate the scene of a car bombing that wounded two officers on Monday.
item.description: A street gang in El Salvador wrapped a mannequin in blankets inside a car, then set off explosives when the police arrived to investigate, wounding two officers.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: 6 Killed in Attack on Church in Burkina Faso
item.description: The violence took place after Sunday services at a church in the country’s north, near the volatile border with Mali. A pastor was among those killed.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.N. Issues Urgent Warning on the Growing Peril of Drug-Resistant Infections
item.media:description: Women wash clothes just outside a river polluted with sewage and waste in the Kibera neighborhood of Nairobi, Kenya. The rate of drug-resistant infections in the community is high.
item.media:credit: Andrew Renneisen for The New York Times
item.description: A new report says the overuse of antimicrobial drugs in humans, animals and plants is fueling resistant pathogens that could kill 10 million people annually by 2050.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Poway Synagogue, Measles, ‘Game of Thrones’: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: REMY TUMIN and SARAH ECKINGER

item.title: Sri Lanka, Japan, ISIS: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.media:description: Residents at a prayer house near St. Anthony’s Shrine in Colombo, Sri Lanka, over a week after the Easter Sunday blasts.
item.description: ISIS leader resurfaces.
item.dc:creator: ALISHA HARIDASANI GUPTA

item.title: Push for Deal Between Kosovo and Serbia Puts National Divisions on Display
item.media:description: A bridge over the Ibar River in Mitrovica, Kosovo, linking an area of the city that is mostly Albanian with one that is mostly Serbian.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The two countries’ presidents have been willing to discuss territorial swaps. But anger among voters is an opportunity for rival politicians, like Kosovo’s prime minister.
item.dc:creator: BARBARA SURK

item.title: For Sri Lanka’s Children, the Deepest Scars Are Not Physical
item.media:description: S. Diduni Nihansa, 5, was wounded in the Easter Sunday bombings in Sri Lanka. Eight days later, she still will not talk.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Some suffered terrible injuries in the bombings. But for many others, witnesses to unimaginable scenes of carnage, the wounds are psychological.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: Eastern Canada Grapples With Extreme Flooding
item.media:description: Canadian police officers on a flooded street in Sainte-Marthe-sur-le-Lac in the suburbs of Montreal, on Sunday.
item.description: Residents in Quebec, Ontario and New Brunswick have been forced to evacuate their homes after extreme flooding some have linked to climate change.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and IAN AUSTEN

item.title: ISIS’ Mysterious Leader Is Not Dead, New Video Shows
item.media:description: The authenticity of the Islamic State video could not be independently verified but terrorism experts saw little reason to doubt that it was the group’s leader, Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.
item.description: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi appeared on video for the first time in five years, reasserting authority in the wake of lost territory and a major attack in Sri Lanka.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
